>I have seen enemy clerics raise the undead.  I have seen enemy druids
>use the spell of protection and summon faeries in my own scenarios.
>The only character I think that is severly deficient in its
>programming are slime.

Yes, the druids have good AI. Clerics... don't. The main reason to use them 
is to heal your other team members and raise ghosts, and they do neither 
under the computer's control (at least, not on a regular basis). Slimes can 
be nasty, if they're out in the open and have room to replicate. In your 
"The Brag", if I accidentally blow the doors open and let the slimes out, 
there's no way to win. I have to pick off the blobs with chain lightning or 
exploding bolts while they're still enclosed. Now, orc commanders... they 
have no real purpose, and could use some further coding. I mean, why do they 
have no abilities? That's crazy. How about... if an orc commander is within 
ten squares of an orc, that orc gets his stats increased by 25%. Or 
something. Also, if towers had a close-range special, "Boiling Oil" or 
something, I think it would make for some fun times. Hehe... boiling oil.

>I had my entire team (1 mega powered archmage) mind controlled once
>and it lasted after the offending archmage was dead.  My team has >been 
>effected by enemy chain lightning in one of the original >scenarios.  I 
>have seen enemy mages freeze time REPEATEDLY in a >certain one of the 
>tevfifty and one of my own scenarios has been >accused of fostering mages 
>that repeatedly freeze time.

Is it a gameplay problem? If there's something wrong with one of my levels, 
I'll fix it. I have to wonder if there are certain conditions under which 
the enemies use more of their abilities than they normally do. I've made 
levels where the enemy mages use warp space a lot, and some where they just 
don't. I can't figure out what triggers them to do this.

>Admittedly, I have not seen enemy archmages summon images or fire
>elementals.  However, those would be extremely to prove an enemy
>archmage would do so unless one created a scenario with 100% named
>characters and no monster generators.

I don't know what you mean.

>I have no my problems with any other mega powered characters except
>faeries.  But faeries, ghosts, and sketelons are not likely to be
>around much once I complete this set and if you go through certain
>scenarios, you should understand my concern about facing faeries and
>ghosts.

I never really liked ghosts. In all honesty, I prefer levels with normal 
humans to play against, like Nilwyn Town.

>Well, in most of my scenarios, there will be no NPCs.  But, if I do
>have an NPC in my scenarios, the NPC will be sufficient to help you
>out in some problems.
>However, one slight note:  I have designed a scenario where a team
>composed entirely of clerics can NOT win [unless you are extremely
>lucky] and that scenario is on the main path.

I think there are some tevfifty levels that a cleric would be useless on 
(like the Slime Machine). They're not good offensive characters, Mystic Mace 
or no Mystic Mace. If your character is fast and has a ranged attack, you 
can pick off a cleric of any level with ease (and some time). That is, 
unless you let yourself get cornered, or kill yourself with your own attack 
(a la Exploding Bolt).

>Yes, I do realize some of my scenarios are not well suited for
>archers, but neither are certain ones of the tevfifty.

Yes, the Stairs are hell with an archer. Mages work best on the thin 
passages.

>I need opinions from more people on this subject of experience level
>15 and higher mages and archmages.
